author: Abc News Breakfast
title: Is Australia handling charity the wrong way? - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
Map: Australia 
Not all charities spend your donated dollars equally and we should take a more rigorous approach to who we support, according to a global social movement that is starting an Australian chapter. 
Philosopher and philanthropist Peter Singer will officially launch the Australian branch of Effective Altruism at an event in Melbourne on Friday night and said the aim of the group was to take a scientific approach to charity. 
"Effective Altruism is an emerging worldwide movement of people who, on the one hand, want to make the world a better place ... but they want to do it on the basis of evidence about what really is going to be the most effective thing they can do," he told ABC News Breakfast. 
"So they are not moved just by images of smiling children or generally thinking that this sounds like a good charity. 
"They really want to look at the research, which is now widely available online, to show what are the most effective ways to help people and to make the world a better place." 
There are more than 54,000 charities registered with the Australian Charities and Not-for-profits Commission and it is estimated the sector has a combined worth of $103 billion. Audio: Why effective altruism could change the world (Life Matters) 
The Effective Altruism group promotes "partner charities" that it says have been "thoroughly and independently investigated, and are supported by swathes of supporting academic literature". 
Professor Singer dismissed suggestions that a calculated approach to donations might go against the spirit of charity for some people. 
"When we want to do things for ourselves, if we want to buy a new laptop, we do research," he said. 
"And if someone told us, 'Oh you could have got just as good a laptop for half the money', we are upset with ourselves. But nobody tells us that, or at least nobody used to tell us that, with charities. 
"And that's what the Effective Altruism movement is trying to do â€” it is putting research out there online that shows which are the most effective charities you can donate to." External Link: Peter Singer TED talk: The why and how of effective altruism Effective Altruism draws critics 
The Effective Altruism philosophy has come under criticism in the past for being "moralistic" and having the potential to push people towards larger, established charities. 
"[It] is an approach that not only unjustifiably claims the moral high ground in giving decisions, but also implements this bold claim by weighing causes and beneficiaries against one another," non-profit sector consultants Ken Berger and Robert Penna wrote in the Stanford Social Innovation Review . 
"In this, it is not moral, but rather, moralistic in the worst sense of the word." 
Professor Singer said the underlying philosophy was simply about making sure each dollar had the biggest impact, and that many smaller charities made the list. 
"In a way [smaller groups] are easier to evaluate," he said. 
"Because charities that do just one thing, like distribute bed nets or prevent people going blind or do cataract operations, they are easy to assess what you are getting for your money." 
Professor Singer will be a key speaker at Friday night's launch and will be joined by 2005 Australian of the Year Fiona Wood and the global lead of development effectiveness at The Fred Hollows Foundation, Kirsten Armstrong.
